overview.p: Menologion for September in Greek. Contains stories of saints' lives and martyrdoms arranged in the order of days the church devotes to their memories. The table of contents (pinax) includes titles and incipits of the daily readings. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Grk. 43.

headpieces.p: Headpieces of multi-colored floral, foliate, and geometric designs at the beginning of each reading, and on the table of contents.

initials.p: Major initials (15-60 mm) of abstract floral and bead motifs in blue, red and yellow, set off from the text.

foliation.p: 1-225. Modern foliation in Arabic numerals in pencil.

collation.p: Originally 31 quires, each of 8 leaves, with the exception of quires 14 and 31 of 5 leaves. Estimate of content lost: quire 30; 3 leaves of quire 28; 6 leaves of quire 29; 2 leaves of quire 31.

The Menologion was composed in two parts. Part one, of 14 readings, ends at September 15 on leaf 5 of quire 14 (fol. 111v). Part two contains 13 readings, and begins at September 15, on leaf 1 of quire 15 (fol. 112r). During the writing process, each part was numbered separately. After binding, the manuscript's quires were sequentially numbered in the lower margin on the first leaf (recto) and last leaf (verso). Quire numbers 1-29, 31 (α-κθ, λα) are extant. Of the initial scheme, all but numbers 12 and 13 of the second section are lost (ιβ fol. 200r, ιΓ fol. 208r).
The pinax or table of contents (fols. 1r-2v) does not correspond fully with headings and incipits, and may have been a later addition to the manuscript.

physDesc.dimensions: Written space 220 x 160 mm (fol. 35r). Each column is 220 x 70 mm with a space of 20 mm between.

layout.p: 2 columns, 33 lines. Ruling with hard point.

handDesc.p: Written in minuscule script in dark brown ink (some flaking).
Punctuation includes high, middle, and low points, marks of interrogation and elision, and quotation marks.

Corrections to the text were made in brown ink, and inaccuracies eliminated by erasure, washing, and strike through. Some marginal text was excised (fols. 74, 154, 157, 159); and, holes were cut in two leaves (fols. 57, 91) with corrected copy supplied in the upper margin of the versos.

condition.p: Outer and lower margins of several leaves cut away or broken off along ruling lines. Some faded letters traced over and omitted letters added in black ink. Creases, tears, insect damage, random holes, and taped repairs. Stained with dirt, water, grease, wax, and ink.

binding.p: Bound in grey-green leather over boards. Leaves cut from a Latin bible serve as pastedowns.

origin.p: The manuscript is judged to have been written in Constantinople, the present-day Istanbul, Turkey, in either the 11th or 12th century.

provenance.p: Inscriptions dated 1303 and 23 November 1309 (fol. 2r). Other additions include a supplied title μεταφρσης σαιπτεβρηος (September Metaphrastes), and the numbering of leaves allotted each reading.

acquisition.p: Acquired by the University of Chicago from Jacques Furst of New York, April 1939.

projectDesc.p: The Edgar J. Goodspeed Manuscript Collection contains 68 Greek, Armenian, Latin, Syriac, Ethiopic, and Arabic manuscripts, which range in date from the fifth to the nineteenth century. With support from the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Leadership Grants for Libraries, Building Digital Resources program, the University of Chicago Library has created the online Goodspeed Manuscript Collection, a unique digital resource with manuscripts digitized in their entirety and presented with high-quality zoomable images through an interface that supports browsing within individual manuscripts and across the collection.

Descriptions of the manuscripts have been encoded using the standard set forth in TEI Consortium, eds., TEI P5 Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange: Manuscript Description, at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/MS.html as of 2012-09-22.

The TEI DTD used was obtained from the Digital Scriptorium of Columbia University at, https://www1.columbia.edu/sec/cu/libraries/bts/digital_scriptorium/technical/ds-xml/description_dtd/index.html on 2012-09-22. To accommodate specific project needs, the DTD was edited and extended with local tags in order to describe the content of miniatures, and the structure of canon tables, headpieces, and initials. The process of editing included equating the element Decoration with the seven recognized elements of the TEI Manuscript Description, not only to emphasize intellectual substance, but also to augment visibility by providing links from the record through encoding to the digitized imagery of the Web display.

msItem.summary: Bible Leaf in Latin. Text of John 14:25-15:4 (from vos manens to semet ipso) written on parchment in two columns (340 x 235 mm).
Table of Contents (Pinax).
September 1: Life of Simeon Stylites.
September 2: Passion of the holy megalomartyr Mamas.
September 3: Passion of the holy hosiomartyr Anthimus, Bishop of Nicomedia.
September 4: Passion of the holy hieromartyr Babylas, Bishop of Antioch.
September 6: Account of the miracle at Chonae by the Archangel Michael.
September 6: Passion of the holy martyrs Eudocius, Romulus, Zeno, and Macarius.
September 7: Passion of the holy martyr Sozon.
September 8: Account of the birth of the Mother of God from the Protevangelium of James the Brother of God.
September 9: Passion of the holy megalomartyr Severianus.
September 10: Passion of the holy women Menodora, Nymphodora, and Metrodora.
September 11: Life and conduct of Theodora of Alexandria.
September 12: Passion of the holy hieromartyr Autonomous.
September 13: Example and conduct of holy Cornelius the Centurion.
September 14: Oration of Andrew the Jerusalemite, Bishop of Crete, concerning the elevation of the precious and life-giving cross.
September 15: Passion of the holy megalomartyr Nicetas.
September 16: Passion of the holy martyr Euphemia.
September 17: Passion of the holy women Sophia and her daughters Pistis, Elpis, and Agape.
September 19: Passion of the holy martyrs Trophimus, Sabbatius, and Dorymedon.
September 20: Passion of the holy megalomartyr Eustace, his wife Theopistis, and his sons Agapius and Theopistus.
September 22: On Phocas the holy martyr of Christ, a panegyric of Asterius, Bishop of Amasea.
September 24: Passion of the holy protomartyr and apostle Thecla.
September 25: Life and conduct of holy Euphrosyne of Alexandria.
September 26: Memorial to the holy apostle and evangelist John the Theologion.
September 27: Passion of the holy megalomartyr Callistratus.
September 28: Life and conduct of the holy father and confessor Chariton.
September 29: Life and conduct of the holy father Cyriacus the Anchorite.
September: 30: Life, conduct, and passion of the holy hieromartyr Gregory of Armenia.
